The **Saint Lawrence River** ([French](/wiki/French_language "French
language"): _Fleuve Saint-Laurent_ ; [Tuscarora](/wiki/Tuscarora_language
"Tuscarora language"): _Kahnawáʼkye_ ;[3] [Mohawk](/wiki/Mohawk_language
"Mohawk language"): _Kaniatarowanenneh_ , meaning "big waterway") is a large
[river](/wiki/River "River") in the middle latitudes of [North
America](/wiki/North_America "North America"). The Saint Lawrence River flows
in a roughly north-easterly direction, connecting the [Great
Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes") with the [Atlantic
Ocean](/wiki/Atlantic_Ocean "Atlantic Ocean") and forming the [primary
drainage outflow](/wiki/Outflow_\(hydrology\) "Outflow \(hydrology\)") of the
[Great Lakes Basin](/wiki/Great_Lakes_Basin "Great Lakes Basin"). It traverses
the [Canadian provinces](/wiki/Provinces_and_territories_of_Canada "Provinces
and territories of Canada") of [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") and
[Ontario](/wiki/Ontario "Ontario"), and is part of the [international
boundary](/wiki/Canada%E2%80%93United_States_border "Canada–United States
border") between Ontario, Canada, and the [U.S. state](/wiki/U.S._state "U.S.
state") of [New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"). This
river also provides the basis of the commercial [Saint Lawrence
Seaway](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_Seaway "Saint Lawrence Seaway").

##
Geography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Lawrence_River&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Geography")]

The Saint Lawrence River begins at the outflow of [Lake
Ontario](/wiki/Lake_Ontario "Lake Ontario") and flows adjacent to
[Gananoque](/wiki/Gananoque,_Ontario "Gananoque, Ontario"),
[Brockville](/wiki/Brockville "Brockville"),
[Morristown](/wiki/Morristown,_New_York "Morristown, New York"),
[Ogdensburg](/wiki/Ogdensburg,_New_York "Ogdensburg, New York"),
[Massena](/wiki/Massena_\(village\),_New_York "Massena \(village\), New
York"), [Cornwall](/wiki/Cornwall,_Ontario "Cornwall, Ontario"),
[Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal"), [Trois-Rivières](/wiki/Trois-
Rivi%C3%A8res "Trois-Rivières"), and [Quebec City](/wiki/Quebec_City "Quebec
City") before draining into the [Gulf of Saint
Lawrence](/wiki/Gulf_of_Saint_Lawrence "Gulf of Saint Lawrence"), the largest
[estuary](/wiki/Estuary "Estuary") in the world.[4] The estuary begins at the
eastern tip of [Île d'Orléans](/wiki/%C3%8Ele_d%27Orl%C3%A9ans "Île
d'Orléans"), just downstream from Quebec City.[2] The river becomes tidal
around Quebec City.[5]

The Saint Lawrence River runs 3,058 [kilometres](/wiki/Kilometre "Kilometre")
(1,900 [mi](/wiki/Mile "Mile")) from the farthest headwater to the mouth and
1,197 km (743.8 mi) from the outflow of Lake Ontario. These numbers include
the estuary; without the estuary the length from Lake Ontario is ca. 500 km
(ca. 300 mi). The farthest headwater is the [North
River](/wiki/North_River_\(Minnesota\) "North River \(Minnesota\)") in the
[Mesabi Range](/wiki/Mesabi_Range "Mesabi Range") at [Hibbing](/wiki/Hibbing
"Hibbing"), Minnesota. Its drainage area, which includes the Great Lakes, the
world's largest system of freshwater lakes, is 1,344,200 square kilometres
(518,998.5 sq mi), of which 839,200 km2 (324,016.9 sq mi) is in Canada and
505,000 km2 (194,981.6 sq mi) is in the United States. The basin covers parts
of [Ontario](/wiki/Ontario "Ontario") and [Quebec](/wiki/Quebec "Quebec") in
Canada, parts of [Illinois](/wiki/Illinois "Illinois"),
[Indiana](/wiki/Indiana "Indiana"), [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota"),
[New York](/wiki/New_York_\(state\) "New York \(state\)"), [Ohio](/wiki/Ohio
"Ohio"), [Pennsylvania](/wiki/Pennsylvania "Pennsylvania"),
[Vermont](/wiki/Vermont "Vermont"), and [Wisconsin](/wiki/Wisconsin
"Wisconsin"), and nearly the entirety of the state of
[Michigan](/wiki/Michigan "Michigan") in the United States. The average
discharge below the [Saguenay River](/wiki/Saguenay_River "Saguenay River") is
16,800 cubic metres per second (590,000 cu ft/s). At Quebec City, it is 12,101
m3/s (427,300 cu ft/s). The average discharge at the river's source, the
outflow of Lake Ontario, is 7,410 m3/s (262,000 cu ft/s).[2]

The Saint Lawrence River includes [Lake Saint-Louis](/wiki/Lake_Saint-Louis
"Lake Saint-Louis") south of [Montreal](/wiki/Montreal "Montreal"), [Lake
Saint Francis](/wiki/Lake_Saint_Francis_\(Canada\) "Lake Saint Francis
\(Canada\)") at [Salaberry-de-Valleyfield](/wiki/Salaberry-de-Valleyfield
"Salaberry-de-Valleyfield") and [Lac Saint-Pierre](/wiki/Lac_Saint-Pierre "Lac
Saint-Pierre") east of Montreal. It encompasses four
[archipelagoes](/wiki/Archipelago "Archipelago"): the [Thousand
Islands](/wiki/Thousand_Islands "Thousand Islands") chain near [Alexandria
Bay, New York](/wiki/Alexandria_Bay,_New_York "Alexandria Bay, New York") and
[Kingston, Ontario](/wiki/Kingston,_Ontario "Kingston, Ontario"); the
[Hochelaga Archipelago](/wiki/Hochelaga_Archipelago "Hochelaga Archipelago"),
including the [Island of Montreal](/wiki/Island_of_Montreal "Island of
Montreal") and [Île Jésus](/wiki/%C3%8Ele_J%C3%A9sus "Île Jésus")
([Laval](/wiki/Laval,_Quebec "Laval, Quebec")); the Lake St. Pierre
Archipelago (classified biosphere world reserve by the UNESCO in 2000)[6] and
the smaller [Mingan Archipelago](/wiki/Mingan_Archipelago "Mingan
Archipelago"). Other islands include Île d'Orléans near Quebec City and
[Anticosti Island](/wiki/Anticosti_Island "Anticosti Island") north of the
[Gaspé](/wiki/Gasp%C3%A9_Peninsula "Gaspé Peninsula"). It is the second
longest river in Canada.

[Lake Champlain](/wiki/Lake_Champlain "Lake Champlain") and the
[Ottawa](/wiki/Ottawa_River "Ottawa River"), [Richelieu](/wiki/Richelieu_River
"Richelieu River"), [Saint-Maurice](/wiki/Saint-Maurice_River "Saint-Maurice
River"), [Saint-François](/wiki/Saint-Francois_River "Saint-Francois River")
and Saguenay rivers drain into the Saint Lawrence.

The Saint Lawrence River is in a seismically active zone where
[fault](/wiki/Fault_\(geology\) "Fault \(geology\)") reactivation is believed
to occur along late [Proterozoic](/wiki/Proterozoic "Proterozoic") to early
[Paleozoic](/wiki/Paleozoic "Paleozoic") normal faults related to the opening
of [Iapetus Ocean](/wiki/Iapetus_Ocean "Iapetus Ocean"). The faults in the
area are [rift](/wiki/Rift "Rift") related and are called the [Saint Lawrence
rift system](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_rift_system "Saint Lawrence rift system").

According to the United States Geological Survey, the Saint Lawrence Valley is
a [physiographic province](/wiki/Physiographic_regions_of_the_world
"Physiographic regions of the world") of the larger
[Appalachian](/wiki/Appalachian_Mountains "Appalachian Mountains") division,
containing the [Champlain](/wiki/Champlain_Valley "Champlain Valley") and
Northern physiographic section.[7] However, in Canada, where most of the
valley is, it is instead considered part of a distinct [Saint Lawrence
Lowlands](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_Lowlands "Saint Lawrence Lowlands")
physiographic division, and not part of the Appalachian division at all.[8]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Lawrence_River&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: History")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/b0/Dauphin_Map_of_Canada_-
_circa_1543_-_Project_Gutenberg_etext_20110.jpg/220px-Dauphin_Map_of_Canada_-
_circa_1543_-_Project_Gutenberg_etext_20110.jpg)](/wiki/File:Dauphin_Map_of_Canada_-
_circa_1543_-_Project_Gutenberg_etext_20110.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Dauphin_Map_of_Canada_-
_circa_1543_-_Project_Gutenberg_etext_20110.jpg "Enlarge")

Map of 1543 showing Cartier's discoveries

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Basques_Newfoundland.gif/220px-
Basques_Newfoundland.gif)](/wiki/File:Basques_Newfoundland.gif)

[](/wiki/File:Basques_Newfoundland.gif "Enlarge")

Basque settlements and sites dating from the 16th and 17th centuries

Though the [Norse](/wiki/Norse_colonization_of_the_Americas "Norse
colonization of the Americas") explored the Gulf of Saint Lawrence in the 11th
century and were followed by fifteenth and early sixteenth century European
mariners, such as [John Cabot](/wiki/John_Cabot "John Cabot"), the brothers
[Gaspar](/wiki/Gaspar_Corte_Real "Gaspar Corte Real"), [Miguel Corte-
Real](/wiki/Miguel_Corte-Real "Miguel Corte-Real"), and [Alonso
Sanchez](/wiki/Alonso_Sanchez "Alonso Sanchez"). The first European explorer
known to have sailed up the Saint Lawrence River itself was [Jacques
Cartier](/wiki/Jacques_Cartier "Jacques Cartier"). At that time, the land
along the river was inhabited by the [St. Lawrence
Iroquoians](/wiki/St._Lawrence_Iroquoians "St. Lawrence Iroquoians"); at the
time of Cartier's second voyage in 1535. Because Cartier arrived in the
estuary on [Saint Lawrence](/wiki/Lawrence_of_Rome "Lawrence of Rome")'s feast
day, he named it the _Gulf of Saint Lawrence_.[9] The Saint Lawrence River is
partly within the U.S. and as such is that country's sixth oldest surviving
European place-name.[10]

The earliest regular Europeans in the area were the
[Basques](/wiki/History_of_the_Basque_people#Modern_Period "History of the
Basque people"), who came to the St Lawrence Gulf and River in pursuit of
whales from the early 16th century. The [Basque
whalers](/wiki/History_of_Basque_whaling "History of Basque whaling") and
fishermen traded with indigenous Americans and set up settlements, leaving
vestiges all over the coast of eastern Canada and deep into the Saint Lawrence
River. Basque commercial and fishing activity reached its peak before the
_[Armada Invencible](/wiki/Armada_Invencible "Armada Invencible")'_s disaster
(1588), when the Spanish Basque whaling fleet was confiscated by King [Philip
II of Spain](/wiki/Philip_II_of_Spain "Philip II of Spain") and largely
destroyed. Initially, the whaling galleons from [Labourd](/wiki/Labourd
"Labourd") were not affected by the Spanish defeat.

Until the early 17th century, the French used the name _Rivière du Canada_ to
designate the Saint Lawrence upstream to Montreal and the Ottawa River after
Montreal. The Saint Lawrence River served as the main route for European
exploration of the North American interior, first pioneered by French explorer
[Samuel de Champlain](/wiki/Samuel_de_Champlain "Samuel de Champlain").

Control of the river was crucial to [British strategy to capture New
France](/wiki/Great_Britain_in_the_Seven_Years_War "Great Britain in the Seven
Years War") in the [Seven Years' War](/wiki/Seven_Years%27_War "Seven Years'
War"). Having [captured Louisbourg](/wiki/Siege_of_Louisbourg_\(1758\) "Siege
of Louisbourg \(1758\)") in 1758, the British sailed up to Quebec the
following year thanks to charts drawn up by [James Cook](/wiki/James_Cook
"James Cook"). British troops were ferried via the Saint Lawrence to attack
the city from the west, which they successfully did at the [Battle of the
Plains of Abraham](/wiki/Battle_of_the_Plains_of_Abraham "Battle of the Plains
of Abraham"). The river was used again by the British [to
defeat](/wiki/Battle_of_Neuville "Battle of Neuville") the French siege of
Quebec under the [Chevalier de Lévis](/wiki/Chevalier_de_L%C3%A9vis "Chevalier
de Lévis") in 1760.

Because of the virtually impassable [Lachine Rapids](/wiki/Lachine_Rapids
"Lachine Rapids"), the Saint Lawrence was once continuously navigable only as
far as Montreal. Opened in 1825, the [Lachine Canal](/wiki/Lachine_Canal
"Lachine Canal") was the first to allow ships to pass the rapids. An extensive
system of canals and locks, known as the [Saint Lawrence
Seaway](/wiki/Saint_Lawrence_Seaway "Saint Lawrence Seaway"), was officially
opened on 26 June 1959 by [Elizabeth II](/wiki/Elizabeth_II "Elizabeth II")
(representing Canada) and President [Dwight D.
Eisenhower](/wiki/Dwight_D._Eisenhower "Dwight D. Eisenhower") (representing
the United States). The Seaway now permits ocean-going vessels to pass all the
way to [Lake Superior](/wiki/Lake_Superior "Lake Superior").

During the [Second World War](/wiki/World_War_II "World War II"), the [Battle
of the St. Lawrence](/wiki/Battle_of_the_St._Lawrence "Battle of the St.
Lawrence") involved submarine and anti-submarine actions throughout the lower
Saint Lawrence River and the entire [Gulf of Saint
Lawrence](/wiki/Gulf_of_Saint_Lawrence "Gulf of Saint Lawrence"), [Strait of
Belle Isle](/wiki/Strait_of_Belle_Isle "Strait of Belle Isle") and [Cabot
Strait](/wiki/Cabot_Strait "Cabot Strait") from May to October 1942, September
1943, and again in October and November 1944. During this time, German
[U-boats](/wiki/U-boat "U-boat") sank several merchant marine ships and three
Canadian warships.

In the late 1970s, the river was the subject of a successful ecological
campaign (called "Save the River"), originally responding to planned
development by the [United States Army Corps of
Engineers](/wiki/United_States_Army_Corps_of_Engineers "United States Army
Corps of Engineers"). The campaign was organized, among others, by [Abbie
Hoffman](/wiki/Abbie_Hoffman "Abbie Hoffman").[_[citation
needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed "Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

##
Sources[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Lawrence_River&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Sources")]

The source of the North River in the [Mesabi Range](/wiki/Mesabi_Range "Mesabi
Range") in [Minnesota](/wiki/Minnesota "Minnesota") (Seven Beaver Lake) is
considered to be the source of the Saint Lawrence River. Because it crosses so
many lakes, the water system frequently changes its name. From source to
mouth, the names are:

  * [North River](/wiki/North_River_\(Minnesota\) "North River \(Minnesota\)")[17]
  * [Saint Louis River](/wiki/Saint_Louis_River "Saint Louis River")[18]
  * [Lake Superior](/wiki/Lake_Superior "Lake Superior")
  * [Saint Marys River](/wiki/St._Marys_River_\(Michigan-Ontario\) "St. Marys River \(Michigan-Ontario\)")
  * [Lake Huron](/wiki/Lake_Huron "Lake Huron")
  * [Saint Clair River](/wiki/St._Clair_River "St. Clair River")
  * [Lake Saint Clair](/wiki/Lake_Saint_Clair_\(North_America\) "Lake Saint Clair \(North America\)")
  * [Detroit River](/wiki/Detroit_River "Detroit River")
  * [Lake Erie](/wiki/Lake_Erie "Lake Erie")
  * [Niagara River](/wiki/Niagara_River "Niagara River")
  * [Lake Ontario](/wiki/Lake_Ontario "Lake Ontario")

The Saint Lawrence River also passes through [Lake Saint-
Louis](/wiki/Lake_Saint-Louis "Lake Saint-Louis") and [Lake Saint-
Pierre](/wiki/Lake_Saint-Pierre "Lake Saint-Pierre") in Quebec.

## Works[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Saint_Lawrence_River&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Works")]

The Saint Lawrence River is at the heart of many Quebec novels ([Anne
Hébert](/wiki/Anne_H%C3%A9bert "Anne Hébert")'s
_[Kamouraska](/wiki/Kamouraska_\(novel\) "Kamouraska \(novel\)")_ , [Réjean
Ducharme](/wiki/R%C3%A9jean_Ducharme "Réjean Ducharme")'s _[L'avalée des
avalés](/w/index.php?title=L%27aval%C3%A9e_des_aval%C3%A9s&action=edit&redlink=1
"L'avalée des avalés \(page does not exist\)")_), poems (in works of [Pierre
Morency](/wiki/Pierre_Morency "Pierre Morency"), [Bernard
Pozier](/w/index.php?title=Bernard_Pozier&action=edit&redlink=1 "Bernard
Pozier \(page does not exist\)")), and songs ([Leonard
Cohen](/wiki/Leonard_Cohen "Leonard Cohen")'s
"[Suzanne](/wiki/Suzanne_\(Leonard_Cohen_song\) "Suzanne \(Leonard Cohen
song\)")", Michel Rivard's "L'oubli", [Joe Dassin](/wiki/Joe_Dassin "Joe
Dassin")'s "[Dans les yeux d'Émilie](/wiki/Dans_les_yeux_d%27%C3%89milie "Dans
les yeux d'Émilie")"), and [André Gagnon](/wiki/Andr%C3%A9_Gagnon "André
Gagnon")'s "Le Saint-Laurent"). The river was the setting for the Canadian
television drama series [Seaway](/wiki/Seaway_\(TV_series\) "Seaway \(TV
series\)"). The river has also been portrayed in paintings, notably by the
[Group of Seven](/wiki/Group_of_Seven_\(artists\) "Group of Seven
\(artists\)"). In addition, the river is the namesake of [Saint-Laurent
Herald](/wiki/Saint-Laurent_Herald "Saint-Laurent Herald") at the [Canadian
Heraldic Authority](/wiki/Canadian_Heraldic_Authority "Canadian Heraldic
Authority").

In 1980 [Jacques Cousteau](/wiki/Jacques_Cousteau "Jacques Cousteau") traveled
to Canada to make two films on the Saint Lawrence River and the [Great
Lakes](/wiki/Great_Lakes "Great Lakes"), _[Cries from the
Deep](/wiki/Cries_from_the_Deep "Cries from the Deep")_ and _St. Lawrence:
Stairway to the Sea_.[19]

Musician [David Usher](/wiki/David_Usher "David Usher") released the song "St.
Lawrence River" on his _[Little
Songs](/wiki/Little_Songs_\(David_Usher_album\) "Little Songs \(David Usher
album\)")_ album in 1998.[20]

The novel and film [Black Robe](/wiki/Black_Robe "Black Robe") is set
primarily on the St. Lawrence River during the 17th century.
